From: "Colin Green" <colin.green1@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Article Documenting How Natural Selection is Not Good at Choosing At Least One of Its Own Parameters (Mutation Rate)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770313; y=v4-rtsPdQVF_2Z0cyTySOTGaGXsJmCouhzdLg2Y_q2fSrWDPyZp6
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

Hi,

I pretty much a gree with Ken's line, that the local problem domain
obscures any selection pressure for any particular mutation rate.
Looked at anothe rway, say there is an optimal mutation rate, chances
are it's benefit over a poor one is so weak as to be drowned out by
the noise/randomness of each run. To perform enough runs to find
statistically significant changes in teh mutation rate would (I would
wager) take amounts of computation several magnitudes greater than
what we have available.

Also if we consider evolution in the real world organisms are
subjected to wide variations in mutation rate, from differing UV light
intensity, background radiation, chemical mutagens, etc. I see all
these 'anomalies' as being an important and central part of evolution
along with extinction events (comet impacts, climate change, the
'switch' to an oxygen atmosphere). Homogenous fitness landscapes and
mutation/crossover schemes were and are a good starting point for
computational evolution, but I think variation and randomness in the
fitness landscape *and* the wider evolution 'scheme' are very
important.

Bottom line: Try a varying mutation rate versus a fixed one regardless
of whetehr it is fixed high or low.

Colin
